#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=CHAPTER II
#Text=I only six when Wee Brown Elspeth was brought to me .
#Text=Jean and Angus were as fond of each other in their silent way as they were of me , and they often went together with me when I was taken out for my walks .
#Text=I was kept in the open air a great deal , and Angus would walk by the side of my small , shaggy Shetland pony and lead him over rough or steep places .
#Text=Sheltie , the pony , was meant for use when we wished to fare farther than a child could walk ; but I was trained to sturdy marching and climbing even from my babyhood .
#Text=Because I so loved the moor , we nearly always rambled there .
#Text=Often we set out early in the morning , and some simple food was carried , so that we need not return to the castle until we chose .

#Text=I would ride Sheltie and walk by turns until we found a place I liked ; then Jean and Angus would sit down among the heather , Sheltie would be secured , and I would wander about and play in my own way .
#Text=I do not think it was in a strange way .
#Text=I think I must have played as almost any lonely little girl might have played .
#Text=I used to find a corner among the bushes and pretend it was my house and that I had little friends who came to play with me .
#Text=I only remember one thing which was not like the ordinary playing of children .
#Text=It was a habit I had of sitting quite still a long time and listening .
#Text=That was what I called it -- “listening . ”
#Text=I was listening to hear if the life on the moor made any sound I could understand .
#Text=I felt as if it might , if I were very still and listened long enough .
#Text=Angus and Jean and I were not afraid of rain and mist and change of weather .
#Text=If we had been we could have had little outdoor life .
#Text=We always carried plaids enough to keep us warm and dry .
#Text=So on this day I speak of we did not turn back when we found ourselves in the midst of a sudden mist .
#Text=We sat down in a sheltered place and waited , knowing it would lift in time .
#Text=The sun had been shining when we set out .
#Text=Angus and Jean were content to sit and guard me while I amused myself .
#Text=They knew I would keep near them and run into no danger .
#Text=I was not an adventurous child .
#Text=I was , in fact , in a more than usually quiet mood that morning .
#Text=The quiet had come upon me when the mist had begun to creep about and inclose us .
#Text=I liked it .
#Text=I liked the sense of being shut in by the soft whiteness I had so often watched from my nursery window in the castle .
#Text=“ People might be walking about , ” I said to Angus when he lifted me from Sheltie ’s back .
#Text=“ We could n’t see them .
#Text=They might be walking . ”
#Text=“ Nothing that would hurt ye , bairnie , ” he answered .
#Text=“ No , they would n’t hurt me , ” I said .
#Text=I had never been afraid that anything on the moor would hurt me .
#Text=I played very little that day .
#Text=The quiet and the mist held me still .
#Text=Soon I sat down and began to “ listen . ”
#Text=After a while I knew that Jean and Angus were watching me , but it did not disturb me .
#Text=They often watched me when they thought I did not know they were doing it .
#Text=I had sat listening for nearly half an hour when I heard the first muffled , slow trampling of horses ’ hoofs .
#Text=I knew what it was even before it drew near enough for me to be conscious of the other sounds -- the jingling of arms and chains and the creaking of leather one notices as troopers pass by .
#Text=Armed and mounted men were coming toward me .
#Text=That was what the sounds meant ; but they seemed faint and distant , though I knew they were really quite near .
#Text=Jean and Angus did not appear to hear them .
#Text=I knew that I only heard them because I had been listening .
#Text=Out of the mist they rode a company of wild-looking men wearing garments such as I had never seen before .
#Text=Most of them were savage and uncouth , and their clothes were disordered and stained as if with hard travel and fight .
#Text=I did not know -- or even ask myself -- why they did not frighten me , but they did not .
#Text=Suddenly I seemed to know that they were brave men and had been doing some brave , hard thing .
#Text=Here and there among them I caught sight of a broken and stained sword , or a dirk with only a hilt left .
#Text=They were all pale , but their wild faces were joyous and triumphant .
#Text=I saw it as they drew near .
#Text=The man who seemed their chieftain was a lean giant who was darker but , under his darkness , paler than the rest .
#Text=On his forehead was a queer , star-shaped scar .
#Text=He rode a black horse , and before him he held close with his left arm a pretty little girl dressed in strange , rich clothes .
#Text=The big man ’s hand was pressed against her breast as he held her ; but though it was a large hand , it did not quite cover a dark-red stain on the embroideries of her dress .
#Text=Her dress was brown , and she had brown hair and soft brown eyes like a little doe ’s .
#Text=The moment I saw her I loved her .
